data.title: Madame Butterfly (1932)
data.meta_description: Pinkerton marries Cho-Cho San in Japan, whilst on shore leave. When he leaves, she keeps his Japanese home as he left it. He returns three years later, having married again in America, and tells Cho-Cho that their affair is over. She has had a child in his absence, who is sent to her family, before she kills herself.
data.text:
"And you speak also the English?"

"Yes, I learned from visiting scholar. She teach me very high class Brooklyn accent."

Young Cho-Cho San (Sylvia Sidney) begins training as a Geisha at a tea house, hoping to attract a suitable husband. Then, US Navy Lieutenant Ben F. Pinkerton (Cary Grant) arrives in Japan for a couple of months, he visits the tea house and is immediately smitten by Cho-Cho. When Pinkerton learns how easy it is in Japan to get divorced, he decides to marry her, even though he has a woman waiting for him in the US ...

The last remaining film in the rather shabby Cary Grant collection, which I tracked down in the depths of some junk shop at some point - "Madame Butterfly" - turns out to be an extremely unpleasant viewing experience upon inspection:

An American (Cary Grant) stationed in Japan marries a young Japanese woman (Silvia Sidney [unfortunately and probably due to the time when the film was made, not a real Japanese woman]) who is trained as a geisha. In the course of this, the "American way of life" is celebrated as free, uncomplicated and culturally superior, everything Japanese is at best jovially smiled at.
